Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2009 04:28PM - edited Jul 10, 2009 09:44PM by KellyJo Hi Violetpedals, It is best to get a biopsy versus just going for the surgery.  My surgeon told me he was 99% sure my lump was benign, but it was not.  It makes a big difference in what type of surgery you have based on the results.  If the tumor is benign, the surgeon will take less tissue.  If it is not, more tissue will be removed to clear the margins.  Because I did not have a biopsy, I ended up having a second surgery to clear the margins and had 17 lymph nodes removed.  If I had known before the surgery, I would have only had one surgery and 6 to 8 nodes removed.  You can always get a biopsy before the surgery to get the results now!  I also waited to have my surgery and wished I had got the biopsy.  The biopsy is not very painful and will give your surgeon data he needs to perform the surgery.  If you are not happy with the surgeon, get another opinion.   Kelly Jo

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2009 07:40PM - edited Jul 10, 2009 09:43PM by KellyJo Hi Violetpedals, Yes, it is normal to be overcome with fear.  Medicine has come a long way and there are millions of people out there who have gone through this.  It appears that your surgeon is on top of things. The thing to do is to be very active in voicing your thoughts and concerns with the surgeon and letting him know if you are not comfortable with waiting until Aug 8.  You can tell him you want the biopsy now and don't want to wait if that will make you feel more comfortable.  I totally get the fear of waiting.  I waited 2 months to get into surgery because my surgeon went on vacation.  A biospy does not take the place of surgery, it just allows the surgeon to know if it is malignant prior to performing the surgery.  Once my tumor was removed and found malignant, I was not able to have a sentinel biopsy of the lymph nodes because the tumor was gone.  Instead, they did an axillary lymph node disection which is more aggressive.  If I had a biopsy previously, then I could have been spared removing 17 lymph nodes which came back negative for cancer.  You can read more about lymph nodes at this link:  www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/fa... I had my cancer 2 years ago and I am doing fine.  I did not have to do chemo, just a lumpectomy and radiation.  Stay positive and read as much as you can to education yourself about your options and do not hesitate to ask questions.
